Well, Bernard Madoff is accused of running a Ponzi scheme, which a lot of us have heard about, but maybe we don't understand exactly how they work.
Basically, Ponzi schemes are really built on three concepts and that's greed, ignorance, and viral marketing.

And so, effectively, what you do if you want to run a Ponzi scheme, which you shouldn't do because you'll go to jail for it, is you offer extraordinarily high returns to investment which - because everybody is greedy, everybody wants to make more money et cetera et cetera.

And then, what you do is you rely on the ignorance of the investors, traditionally and historically meaning the inability of the investor to understand complicated financial terms like global currency arbitrage, hedge futures trading, things like that.
You make it sound sophisticated.

And then you rely on viral marketing because when people make money, they tend to talk about it, and effectively, though, at the end of the day, you're robbing Peter to pay Paul because the initial investors get their returns, which tend to be very high, from the latter investors and eventually, the whole scheme come crumbling down.
And that's what Madoff is accused of doing.
How does this affect non-profits?
Well, a lot of people invested in Madoff's scheme.
It was the largest Ponzi scheme in American history.
